intro: Haplopappus parryi, commonly known as Parry's pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats, showcasing its adaptability to arid environments. Its small, yellowish flowers are followed by fluffy, wind-dispersed seeds, aiding in its propagation. Haplopappus parryi is often found in desert and sagebrush ecosystems, contributing to the biodiversity of these regions.
